commands.name: touch
commands.description:
The touch command in Linux is used to create new empty files or update the access and modification timestamps of existing files. It's commonly used to:
1) Create new empty files quickly
2) Update file timestamps without modifying content
3) Ensure files exist before other operations
4) Set specific timestamps for files

The command works by updating the file's access time (atime), modification time (mtime), and change time (ctime) to the current time by default.

-a.name: Access Time Only
-a.description: Update only the access time of the file, not the modification time

-c.name: No Create
-c.description: Do not create the file if it does not exist. Only update timestamps of existing files

-d.name: Custom Date/Time
-d.description: Use specified date/time string instead of current time. Accepts various date formats

-h.name: Dereference Symbolic Links
-h.description: Affect the target of symbolic links instead of the links themselves (when supported)

-m.name: Modification Time Only
-m.description: Update only the modification time, not the access time

-r.name: Reference File
-r.description: Use the timestamps from a reference file instead of current time

no_flags.output: Creates 'file.txt' if it doesn't exist, or updates its timestamps to current time if it exists

-a.output: Updates only the access time of 'logfile.txt' to current time without changing modification time

-c.output: No file is created. If 'nonexistent.txt' doesn't exist, nothing happens

-d.output: Sets all timestamps of 'file.txt' to January 15, 2024, 2:30 PM

-h.output: Updates timestamps of the file that symlink_to_file points to

-m.output: Updates only the modification time of 'document.pdf' to current time

-r.output: Sets timestamps of 'target.txt' to match those of 'source.txt'

--help.output: Displays comprehensive help information about touch command usage and options

--version.output: Displays version information of the touch command

--no-dereference.output: Treats 'mysymlink' as a regular file regardless of whether it's a symbolic link

commands.name: 7z
commands.description: 7-Zip is a high-compression file archiver supporting multiple formats including, ZIP, GZIP, TAR, and more. It features LZMA and LZMA2 compression algorithms offering high compression ratios, strong AES-256 encryption, self-extracting archives, and multi-volume archive support. It's a command-line alternative to GUI archive managers with extensive options for compression, extraction, testing, and archive management.

a.name: Add to archive
a.description: Add files to archive or create new archive. This is the primary command for creating or modifying archives.

d.name: Delete from archive
d.description: Delete files from archive. Removes specified files from an existing archive.

e.name: Extract
e.description: Extract files from archive (without directory structure). Files are extracted to current directory without preserving folder hierarchy.

x.name: Extract with full paths
x.description: Extract files from archive with full paths. Preserves the complete directory structure as stored in the archive.

l.name: List contents
l.description: List contents of archive. Shows detailed information about files in archive including size, compression ratio, date, and attributes.

t.name: Test archive
t.description: Test integrity of archive. Verifies that archive is not corrupted and all files can be extracted correctly.

u.name: Update archive
u.description: Update files to archive. Adds files that are newer or don't exist in the archive.

b.name: Benchmark
b.description: Benchmark CPU and memory. Tests compression/decompression speed and memory usage with various algorithms.

i.name: Show information
i.description: Show information about supported formats. Lists all archive formats and codecs that 7-Zip supports.

rn.name: Rename files
rn.description: Rename files in archive. Changes names of files within the archive without extracting.

-t{format}.name: Archive type
-t{format}.description: Specify archive type. Determines the format of the archive to create or operate on.

-m{method}.name: Compression method
-m{method}.description: Set compression method. Controls the algorithm used for compression.

-mx{N}.name: Compression level
-mx{N}.description: Set compression level (0-9). Higher numbers give better compression but are slower.

-mhe.name: Header encryption
-mhe.description: Enable archive header encryption (7z format only). Encrypts file names and metadata.

-p{password}.name: Password
-p{password}.description: Set password for encryption/decryption. Secures archive with AES-256 encryption.

-o{dir}.name: Output directory
-o{dir}.description: Set output directory for extraction. Specifies where extracted files should be placed.

-r.name: Recurse subdirectories
-r.description: Recurse subdirectories. Processes all files in specified directory and its subdirectories.

-sfx.name: Create SFX archive
-sfx.description: Create self-extracting archive. Generates an executable that can extract itself without 7-Zip installed.

-v {size}.name: Create volumes
-v {size}.description: Create multi-volume archive. Splits archive into multiple parts of specified size.

-sdel.name: Delete after compression
-sdel.description: Delete files after adding to archive. Removes original files after successful compression.

-snl.name: Store symbolic links
-snl.description: Store symbolic links instead of following them. Preserves symlinks as links rather than copying target files.

-snh.name: Store hard links
-snh.description: Store hard links instead of following them. Preserves hard links rather than storing duplicate files.

commands.name: add-apt-repository
commands.description: The add-apt-repository command is used to add Personal Package Archives (PPA) repositories or other external repositories to the APT package management system's sources list. PPAs are software repositories hosted on Launchpad that allow developers to distribute software updates directly to Debian users. This command simplifies repository management by automatically fetching the GPG key, adding the repository to /etc/apt/sources.list.d/, and updating the package cache. It's commonly used to install software not available in official repositories or to get newer versions of packages.

--remove.name: Remove
--remove.description: Remove the specified repository from the system instead of adding it. This will delete the repository source file from /etc/apt/sources.list.d/ and update the package cache.

--yes.name: Automatic Yes
--yes.description: Automatically answer 'yes' to all prompts. This is useful for non-interactive scripts where user confirmation is not desired. It will automatically accept repository addition and GPG key import.

--no-update.name: No Update
--no-update.description: Do not update the package cache after adding the repository. This prevents automatic 'apt-get update' execution, allowing you to manually update later.

--enable-source.name: Enable Source
--enable-source.description: Also download the source repository for the specified PPA. This adds a 'deb-src' line to the sources, allowing source code downloading with 'apt-get source'.

--help.name: Help
--help.description: Display help information about the command usage and available options.

no_flags.output: Repository: 'deb http://ppa.launchpad.net/deadsnakes/ppa/ubuntu focal main' added to /etc/apt/sources.list.d/deadsnakes-ubuntu-ppa-focal.list. GPG key imported. Running 'apt update'...

remove.output: Repository 'ppa:deadsnakes/ppa' removed from /etc/apt/sources.list.d/deadsnakes-ubuntu-ppa-focal.list. Package cache updated.

yes.output: Repository added and GPG key imported automatically without prompts. Package cache updated.

no-update.output: Repository added to sources list. Note: Package cache NOT updated (use -n flag).

enable-source.output: Added both binary and source repositories. deb http://ppa.launchpad.net/git-core/ppa/ubuntu focal main and deb-src http://ppa.launchpad.net/git-core/ppa/ubuntu focal main

help.output:
Usage: add-apt-repository [OPTIONS] REPOSITORY

Options:
  -h, --help            show this help message and exit
  -m, --massive-debug   Print a lot of debug information to the command line
  -r, --remove          Remove the specified repository
  -y, --yes             Assume yes to all queries
  -n, --no-update       Do not update package cache after adding
  -s, --enable-source   Allow downloading of the source packages from the repository
  -c, --check           Check repository URL for validity before adding

commands.name: addpart
commands.description: addpart is a utility for informing the Linux kernel about the existence of a new partition on a block device. It does not modify the partition table on disk; it only tells the running kernel about the partition's existence. This is useful after creating a partition with tools that do not automatically inform the kernel, or when partitions are created on a device while the system is not running (e.g., on another system). The command is part of the util-linux package.

-h.name: Help
-h.description: Display a help message and exit.

--help.name: Help (long form)
--help.description: Display a help message and exit.

no_flags.output: No output on success. Informs the kernel that partition 1 exists on /dev/sdb, starting at sector 2048 with a length of 1048576 sectors.

commands.name: alias
commands.description: The alias command creates or lists temporary command aliases in the current shell session. An alias is a shortcut that maps a custom name to a longer command or command sequence, including arguments and options. Aliases created with this command are shell-specific and only persist for the duration of the current terminal session. To make aliases permanent, they must be added to shell startup files like ~/.bashrc, ~/.bash_aliases, or ~/.zshrc. Aliases are expanded before execution, and shell functions or scripts with the same name take precedence. The command can display existing aliases and their definitions when used without arguments or with the -p flag.

-p.name: Print Aliases
-p.description: Prints all currently defined aliases in a format that can be reused as input. The output displays each alias in the format 'alias NAME=VALUE', making it suitable for saving to a configuration file.

no_flags.output: Lists all currently defined aliases in the shell session

-p.output:
alias ll='ls -alF'
alias grep='grep --color=auto'
alias cls='clear'

commands.name: apt
commands.description: Advanced Package Tool (APT) is a package management system for Debian-based Linux distributions. It provides commands for installing, updating, upgrading, removing, and searching for software packages, as well as managing package repositories. APT handles dependencies automatically, fetching and installing all required packages.

install.name: Install packages
install.description: Installs one or more packages. The package names should be specified after the command. APT will automatically resolve and install dependencies.

remove.name: Remove packages
remove.description: Removes one or more installed packages while leaving configuration files on the system.

purge.name: Purge packages
purge.description: Completely removes one or more packages, including configuration files and other data associated with the package.

update.name: Update package lists
update.description: Downloads the latest package information from all configured repositories. This command does not install or upgrade any packages; it only updates APT's database of available packages.

upgrade.name: Upgrade packages
upgrade.description: Upgrades all installed packages to their latest available versions, based on the package lists last updated with 'apt update'. It does not remove packages or install new ones that weren't already installed.

full-upgrade.name: Full upgrade (dist-upgrade)
full-upgrade.description: Upgrades all installed packages, and may remove obsolete packages or install new dependencies as needed to complete the upgrade. This is more aggressive than 'upgrade' and is used for distribution upgrades.

autoremove.name: Auto remove
autoremove.description: Removes packages that were automatically installed to satisfy dependencies for other packages and are no longer needed.

search.name: Search packages
search.description: Searches the list of available packages for the given keyword in package names and descriptions.

show.name: Show package information
show.description: Displays detailed information about a specific package, including version, dependencies, size, and description.

list.name: List packages
list.description: Lists packages based on criteria. Without options, lists all available packages. Can be used with --installed or --upgradable.

edit-sources.name: Edit sources list
edit-sources.description: Opens the sources.list file and associated files in the default text editor for manual editing of repository configurations.

clean.name: Clean package cache
clean.description: Clears the local repository of retrieved package files, removing everything from the package cache (/var/cache/apt/archives).

autoclean.name: Auto clean package cache
autoclean.description: Removes package files from the cache that can no longer be downloaded (obsolete packages).

help.name: Display help
help.description: Displays a brief help message with common APT commands.

no_flags.output: help information for the command

install.output: (Standard installation output showing package downloads and installation progress)

remove.output: (Standard removal output showing package removal progress)

purge.output: (Standard purge output showing complete removal including config files)

update.output: (Standard output showing repository updates and package list downloads)

upgrade.output: (Standard output showing packages to be upgraded and upgrade progress)

full-upgrade.output: (Standard output showing packages to be upgraded/removed/installed)

autoremove.output: (Standard output showing obsolete packages to be removed)

search.output: (List of packages matching 'texteditor' in name or description)

show.output: Detailed information for the vim package

list.output: (List of installed packages containing 'python' in their name)

edit-sources.output: Opens the default editor with the sources list file

clean.output: (No output on success, cache directory is emptied)

autoclean.output: (Output showing obsolete package files being removed)

commands.name: apt-cache
commands.description: apt-cache is a low-level command-line tool for querying information from APT's binary cache files. APT (Advanced Package Tool) is the package management system used by Debian, Ubuntu, and related Linux distributions. The cache contains metadata about available packages, their versions, dependencies, and descriptions, gathered from sources listed in `/etc/apt/sources.list` and files in `/etc/apt/sources.list.d/`. apt-cache does not install, remove, or modify packages; it is purely for querying information. It is essential for searching for packages, investigating dependencies, and checking package details before installation.

search.name: search
search.description: Searches the list of available package names for the given regular expression pattern. It performs a substring search on package names and their descriptions, returning a list of matches. The search is case-insensitive.

show.name: show
show.description: Displays detailed information about a specific package (or packages). This includes the package name, version, architecture, dependencies, size, maintainer, homepage, and a full description. If multiple package names are given, it shows info for each.

showpkg.name: showpkg
showpkg.description: Shows raw information about a package, focusing on its relationships. This includes a list of forward dependencies (what this package depends on), reverse dependencies (which packages depend on this one), and a list of available versions from the repository. It presents data in a more technical, dependency-focused format than `show`.

stats.name: stats
stats.description: Displays statistics about the APT cache. This includes the total number of package names, total number of package versions, total number of dependencies, total number of virtual packages, and the total size of the cache data.

policy.name: policy
policy.description: Displays the source priority configuration (pin preferences) for each package, or for a specified package. It shows which version would be installed from which repository based on priority, including candidate, installed, and version table. Crucial for understanding version pinning.

depends.name: depends
depends.description: Lists every package that the specified package depends on (its dependencies), recursively. It shows a tree of dependencies, including alternatives (e.g., `libc6 | libc6.1`). The output shows the dependency chain and which packages would satisfy each requirement.

rdepends.name: rdepends
rdepends.description: Lists every package that depends on the specified package (its reverse dependencies). It can be run recursively to show the full tree of packages that require the given package, either directly or indirectly.

pkgnames.name: pkgnames
pkgnames.description: Lists the names of all packages in the system, or only those starting with a given prefix. This command is useful for scripting or getting a quick list of available packages. Without a prefix, it outputs a very long list.

dotty.name: dotty
dotty.description: Generates a DOT-formatted graph of the dependency relationships between a set of packages. The output can be piped to a tool like `graphviz` to create a visual diagram. It requires one or more package names as arguments.

xvfb.name: xvfb
xvfb.description: An internal helper for `dotty`. It runs the `dotty` command in a virtual X server environment (Xvfb) to generate a PostScript file automatically. Rarely used directly by end-users.

dump.name: dump
dump.description: Dumps the entire contents of the cache as a raw, machine-readable list. It outputs a very large amount of data, showing every record in the cache. Used primarily for debugging.

dumpavail.name: dumpavail
dumpavail.description: Dumps a list of all available packages from the cache in a format similar to the `dpkg` status file. This output can be parsed by other tools or used to check the universe of installable packages.

unmet.name: unmet
unmet.description: Shows a summary of unmet dependencies in the system. This lists dependencies that are required by installed or available packages but are not currently satisfiable by any installable package. Useful for diagnosing broken package states.

showauto.name: showauto
showauto.description: Lists packages that were automatically installed as dependencies of other packages (i.e., marked as 'auto'). This can be run with `grep` to check if a specific package is auto-installed.

showsrc.name: showsrc
showsrc.description: Shows information about source packages. This is similar to `apt-cache show` but for source packages, listing details like the source package name, version, maintainer, and binary packages it builds.

gencaches.name: gencaches
gencaches.description: Creates the APT package cache. This is equivalent to running `apt-get update`, as it fetches the latest package lists from repositories and builds the local cache. Requires superuser privileges.

no_flags.output: Standard help information for the command.

search.output:
apache2 - Apache HTTP Server
nginx - small, powerful, scalable web/proxy server
lighttpd - fast, secure web server

show.output:

xvfb.output: The command runs internally to generate a PostScript file in a virtual X environment. Output is a file, not terminal text.

dump.output: The output is an extremely long, raw dump of the entire cache. The example shows only the first 20 lines.

dumpavail.output:
Package: bash
Package: bash-completion
Package: bash-doc

unmet.output: If no unmet dependencies exist, the command produces no output.

showsrc.output:
Package: nginx
Binary: nginx, nginx-doc, nginx-common, nginx-full, nginx-light ... (source package details)

gencaches.output: Standard output from updating the package lists (similar to apt-get update).

commands.name: apt-add-repository
commands.description: Adds external APT repository definitions to the system's software sources. This command manages repository entries in files under /etc/apt/sources.list.d/ and /etc/apt/sources.list, allowing users to install software from third-party repositories not included in the default Ubuntu/Debian archives. It can handle both PPA (Personal Package Archive) shortcuts (like 'ppa:user/repo') and full deb line repository URLs. After adding a repository, it typically updates the package cache automatically.

help.name: Help
help.description: Displays a help message with usage information and available options.

remove.name: Remove Repository
remove.description: Removes the specified repository from the system's software sources instead of adding it.

update.name: Update Package Cache
update.description: Runs 'apt-get update' after adding or removing the repository to refresh the package list. This is the default behavior.

no_update.name: Do Not Update
no_update.description: Prevents automatic running of 'apt-get update' after the operation. The repository is added or removed, but the package cache is not refreshed.

enable_source.name: Enable Source Packages
enable_source.description: Also downloads the source packages for the repository by adding a 'deb-src' line in addition to the standard 'deb' line.

component.name: Override Component
component.description: Overrides the default component (often 'main') used when expanding a PPA shortcut. The component is specified as an extra argument after the repository.

keyserver.name: Specify Keyserver
keyserver.description: Specifies a custom keyserver URL to use for retrieving the GPG key associated with the repository, instead of the default keyserver.

dry_run.name: Dry Run
dry_run.description: Performs a simulation of the actions without actually making any changes to the system. Useful for testing.

no_flags.output: Output is standard repository addition confirmation and apt-get update output.

remove.output: Output is standard repository removal confirmation and apt-get update output.

no_update.output: Repository is added but package cache is not updated.

enable_source.output: Adds both 'deb' and 'deb-src' lines for the repository.

component.command: sudo apt-add-repository -c contrib 'deb http://archive.example.com/debian stable main contrib'
component.output: Adds the repository with the 'contrib' component explicitly set.

keyserver.command: sudo apt-add-repository --keyserver hkp://keyserver.ubuntu.com:80 'deb http://packages.example.com/repo stable main'
keyserver.output: Adds repository, fetching GPG key from the specified keyserver.

dry_run.output: Simulation output showing what would be done without making changes.

commands.name: apt-cdrom
commands.description: apt-cdrom is a command-line tool used to manage CD-ROM/DVD-ROM entries in the APT (Advanced Package Tool) sources list file (/etc/apt/sources.list). Its primary purpose is to add a new CD-ROM or DVD-ROM as an installation source for Debian-based systems like Ubuntu, allowing users to install packages from physical media when internet access is unavailable. The command can identify the disc, mount it, read its package information, and add an appropriate entry to the sources list. It also supports features like scanning for multiple discs in a set and adding them with volume identifiers.

-a.name: Add a CD-ROM
-a.description: Prompts the user to mount the CD-ROM/DVD-ROM and then adds it to the system's APT sources list. It identifies the disc and configures APT to use it as a package source.

-d.name: CD-ROM Mount Point
-d.description: Specifies an alternative mount point for the CD-ROM/DVD-ROM, overriding the default location. Must be followed by a path (e.g., -d /mnt/cdrom).

-r.name: Rename
-r.description: Renames a recognized CD-ROM/DVD-ROM volume identifier. Useful for labeling discs with custom names in the APT sources list.

-m.name: No Mounting
-m.description: Assumes the CD-ROM/DVD-ROM is already mounted and skips the mounting step. Use this if you have manually mounted the disc before running apt-cdrom.

-f.name: Fast Copy
-f.description: Forces a fast copy of the CD-ROM/DVD-ROM database, bypassing some file checks. This speeds up the process but may skip validation.

-h.name: Help
-h.description: Displays a brief help message summarizing the available command-line options and usage.

--no-auto-detect.name: Disable Auto-Detect
--no-auto-detect.description: Disables the automatic detection of CD-ROM/DVD-ROM drive paths. Use this if auto-detection fails or to specify a custom drive.

--no-mount.name: No Mounting (Long Form)
--no-mount.description: Same as -m; assumes the CD-ROM/DVD-ROM is already mounted and skips the mounting step.

--cdrom.name: Specify Device
--cdrom.description: Explicitly specifies the CD-ROM/DVD-ROM device file (e.g., /dev/cdrom). Useful if the device is not at the standard location.

--no-act.name: Dry Run
--no-act.description: Performs a simulation of the actions without actually making any changes to the system. Shows what would be done.

no_flags.output: Standard interactive prompts to insert a disc, mount it, and add it to the sources list.

-a.output: Same as 'apt-cdrom add'; interactive prompts to add a CD-ROM.

-d.output: Uses /media/custom as the mount point to add the CD-ROM source.

-r.output: Adds the CD-ROM and renames its volume identifier to "MyDebianDisc" in the sources list.

-m.output: Adds a CD-ROM that is already manually mounted at /mnt/cdrom.

-f.output: Adds a CD-ROM with fast copying of the package database.

--no-auto-detect.output: Adds a DVD-ROM from /mnt/dvd without attempting to auto-detect the drive path.

--no-mount.output: Same as -m; adds a CD-ROM without mounting (assumes already mounted).

--cdrom.output: Specifies /dev/dvd as the device to use for adding the CD-ROM/DVD-ROM.

--no-act.output: Simulates the process of adding a CD-ROM without making actual changes.

commands.name: apt-config
commands.description: A utility for querying and managing the APT (Advanced Package Tool) configuration. It reads the configuration from various sources (/etc/apt/apt.conf, /etc/apt/apt.conf.d/, environment variables) and provides an interface to retrieve configuration values, dump the entire configuration, or manipulate configuration options. It is a key tool for understanding how APT will behave and for debugging configuration issues.

--dump.name: Dump Configuration
--dump.description: Prints a list of all configuration options grouped by the source file they were read from. This is useful for seeing the complete, effective configuration.

dump --empty.name: Include Empty Values
dump --empty.description: When used with `dump`, includes configuration options that have no value set (i.e., are empty). By default, empty values are omitted.

--shell.name: Shell Format
--shell.description: Outputs the configuration in a shell-sourceable format. Each line is a shell variable assignment (e.g., APT::Architecture="amd64"), making it easy to use APT config values in scripts.

shell -v.name: Shell Format with Variable Names
shell -v.description: When used with `--shell`, this flag (or the short `-v`) modifies the output to use proper shell variable names, converting colons and other special characters to underscores (e.g., APT_Architecture="amd64").

-c, --config-file.name: Specify Config File
-c, --config-file.description: Specifies a configuration file to read *in addition to* the default APT configuration files. Can be used multiple times. This is crucial for testing configuration changes without modifying system files.

-o, --option.name: Set Configuration Option
-o, --option.description: Sets an arbitrary configuration option directly on the command line. The syntax is `-o 'Group::Option=Value'`. This overrides settings from any configuration file and is useful for one-time command behavior changes.

-h, --help.name: Help
-h, --help.description: Displays a concise help message summarizing the command usage and available options.

-v, --version.name: Version
-v, --version.description: Displays the version information of the apt-config program and the APT library it uses.

no_flags.output: APT::Architecture="amd64"

-c, --config-file.output: # Output will reflect settings from both default configs and ./test.conf

-h, --help.output:
apt 2.9.2 (amd64)
Usage: apt-config [options] shell [pattern]
       apt-config [options] dump [pattern]
... (help text continues)

commands.name: apt-extracttemplates
commands.description: A utility from the apt package suite that extracts template files from Debian packages. It is primarily used by package maintainers and system administrators to generate configuration files and other templated data from .deb packages before installation. The tool reads the package's template configuration files, processes them, and can produce outputs for user interaction or automated configuration. It's typically invoked by higher-level tools like 'debconf' during package installation and configuration.

--help.name: Help
--help.description: Display a brief help message explaining the command's purpose and basic usage syntax.

-h.name: Help (Short)
-h.description: Short form for displaying help information.

--version.name: Version
--version.description: Display the version information of the apt-extracttemplates utility and exit.

-t.name: Templates Directory
-t.description: Specify a non-default directory where the extracted template files should be written. The default is usually a temporary directory.

--temp-dir.name: Templates Directory (Long)
--temp-dir.description: Long form for specifying the output directory for extracted templates.

no_flags.output: Extracts templates from the specified nginx .deb package to the default temporary directory. Outputs lines like: 'nginx: templates <list_of_files>' to stdout.

--help.output:
Usage: apt-extracttemplates [options] package-file [package-file ...]

Extract configuration scripts and templates from Debian packages.

Options:
  -h, --help            Show this help message and exit.
  --version             Show program's version number and exit.
  -t, --temp-dir=<dir>  Write extracted templates to <dir>.

Report bugs to <aptitude-devel@lists.alioth.debian.org>.

-t.output: Extracts configuration templates from the openssh-server package and writes them directly to the '/tmp/my_templates' directory instead of a system-managed temp location.

--temp-dir.output: Processes multiple package files ('some-package_1.0.deb' and 'another-package_2.0.deb') and deposits all extracted template files into the '/root/pkg-templates' directory.

commands.name: apt-ftparchive
commands.description: A powerful utility for generating APT repository metadata files (Packages, Sources, Contents, Release) from a directory tree of Debian packages. It's used to create and manage APT repositories, generating the necessary index files that APT clients use to discover available packages, their versions, dependencies, and other metadata. It can process binary packages (.deb), source packages (.dsc), and create compressed indexes. This tool is essential for maintaining custom Debian/Ubuntu repositories.

-s, --source.name: Source Configuration
-s, --source.description: Specifies a configuration file that defines the source (package origin) sections for generating the Sources index file for source packages.

-c, --config-file.name: Configuration File
-c, --config-file.description: Specifies the main configuration file. This file contains sections like 'Tree', 'Directory', 'BinOverride', etc., defining how to process the package archive and generate indices.

-d, --db.name: Use Binary Cache DB
-d, --db.description: Uses a binary caching database instead of reading all .deb files directly. This can significantly speed up index generation on subsequent runs by caching package metadata.

--contents.name: Generate Contents Index
--contents.description: Forces the generation of a 'Contents' index file (e.g., Contents-amd64.gz), which maps files to the packages that contain them. This is a resource-intensive operation.

--read-only.name: Read-Only DB
--read-only.description: Opens the binary caching database in read-only mode. Useful when you want to ensure the database is not modified during the index generation process.

-q, --quiet.name: Quiet Mode
-q, --quiet.description: Suppresses progress information and other non-critical output, producing only error messages.

--delink.name: Delink Mode
--delink.description: Operates in 'delink' mode, which is used to prune symlinks from the repository, often used with the 'clean' command to remove outdated package files.

-a, --arch.name: Architecture
-a, --arch.description: Limits processing to packages of the specified architecture (e.g., amd64, arm64, all).

-h, --help.name: Help
-h, --help.description: Displays a summary of the available command-line options and commands.

--version.name: Version
--version.description: Displays the program's version information and exits.

no_flags.output: # Creates a basic, uncompressed Packages file listing all .deb packages in the current directory. This is the simplest use case for a small, local repository.

-c, --config-file.output: # Generates all repository indices (Packages, Sources, Release) as defined in the comprehensive configuration file 'my-repo.conf'. This is the standard way to generate a full repository.

-s, --source.output: # Generates a Sources index file for source packages using source definitions from 'src.conf', while potentially referencing binary configuration from 'bin.conf'.

-d, --db.output: # Generates indices using a binary cache database for faster processing. The first run creates the DB; subsequent runs are much faster.

--contents.output: # Generates the standard indices AND the large 'Contents-amd64.gz' file, which lists all files inside all packages. This can take a long time and use significant disk space.

-a, --arch.output: # Creates a Packages file containing only packages for the 'amd64' architecture, ignoring packages for 'i386' or 'all'.

--delink.output: # Cleans the repository, removing obsolete package files and pruning symlinks as part of the cleanup process.

-q, --quiet.output: # Runs the repository generation silently. No progress output is shown, only errors (if any). Useful for cron jobs or scripts.

commands.name: apt-key
commands.description: apt-key is a command-line utility for managing the list of keys used by apt to authenticate packages. It handles the APT keyrings, which store GPG public keys of package repositories to verify that packages are from trusted sources. This command was commonly used in Debian and Ubuntu systems before the deprecation in favor of more secure methods like signed repository metadata. Note: apt-key is deprecated as of APT 2.4 and later, and its use is discouraged in favor of placing keys directly in /etc/apt/trusted.gpg.d/ or using signed repository metadata.

add.name: Add key
add.description: Add a new key to the trusted keyring. Reads the key from a file or standard input.

del.name: Delete key
del.description: Remove a key from the trusted keyring by its key ID.

export.name: Export key
export.description: Export keys from the trusted keyring. Without arguments, exports all keys. With a key ID, exports only that key.

exportall.name: Export all keys
exportall.description: Export all keys from the trusted keyring to standard output.

fingerprint.name: List fingerprints
fingerprint.description: List fingerprints of all keys in the trusted keyring, or only the specified key.

adv.name: Advanced GPG operations
adv.description: Pass advanced options to GPG. This allows using GPG commands directly on the keyring.

list.name: List keys
list.description: List all keys in the trusted keyring with their details (equivalent to apt-key finger).

update.name: Update keyring
update.description: Update the keyring by fetching missing keys from keyservers (deprecated and often non-functional).

net-update.name: Network update
net-update.description: Update the keyring from keyservers, similar to 'update' but with network operations.

no_flags.output:
pub   rsa2048 2018-04-18 [SC]
      1234 5678 9ABC DEF0 1234  5678 9ABC DEF0 1234 5678
uid           [ unknown] Example Repository Key <repo@example.com>
sub   rsa2048 2018-04-18 [E]

fingerprint.output:
pub   rsa2048 2018-04-18 [SC]
      1234 5678 9ABC DEF0 1234  5678 9ABC DEF0 1234 5678
uid           [ unknown] Example Repository Key <repo@example.com>

adv.output:
gpg: key 9ABCDEF0: public key "Example Repository Key <repo@example.com>" imported
gpg: Total number processed: 1
gpg:               imported: 1

list.output:
pub   rsa2048 2018-04-18 [SC]
      1234 5678 9ABC DEF0 1234  5678 9ABC DEF0 1234 5678
uid           [ unknown] Example Repository Key <repo@example.com>

update.output:
gpg: keyring `/etc/apt/trusted.gpg' created
gpg: /etc/apt/trusted.gpg: trustdb created

net-update.output:
gpg: refreshing 1 key from hkps://keyserver.ubuntu.com
gpg: key 9ABCDEF0: "Example Repository Key <repo@example.com>" 1 new signature

commands.name: apt-get
commands.description: The apt-get command is a high-level command-line tool for managing Debian and Ubuntu packages. It is used to install, remove, update, upgrade, and manage APT (Advanced Package Tool) packages and their dependencies from configured repositories. It works with a local database of packages (the APT cache) which is updated via 'apt-get update'. It is the primary tool for package management in terminal environments.

update.name: Update
update.description: Downloads the latest package lists from the configured repositories (defined in /etc/apt/sources.list and /etc/apt/sources.list.d/). This command does not install or upgrade any packages; it only refreshes the local APT cache with the latest version and dependency information. It must be run before performing a system upgrade or installing new packages to ensure apt-get knows about the latest available versions.

upgrade.name: Upgrade
upgrade.description: Installs the newest versions of all currently installed packages. It will not remove packages or install new ones that weren't already installed. If a package upgrade requires a new dependency, that package will NOT be upgraded. Use 'dist-upgrade' for a more comprehensive upgrade. This command respects 'held' packages.

dist-upgrade.name: Distribution Upgrade
dist-upgrade.description: A more intelligent upgrade handler than 'upgrade'. It performs dependency resolution and can install new packages to satisfy dependencies, and remove obsolete packages if necessary. This is the command used for major distribution version upgrades (e.g., from Ubuntu 20.04 to 22.04). It may remove packages in some cases.

install.name: Install
install.description: Installs one or more packages specified by name. It automatically retrieves and installs the packages and all required dependencies from the configured repositories. Multiple package names can be provided separated by spaces.

remove.name: Remove
remove.description: Removes one or more installed packages, but leaves configuration files on the system. This is useful if you plan to reinstall the package later and keep its settings. It does not remove dependencies that were automatically installed and are no longer needed (see 'autoremove').

purge.name: Purge
purge.description: Completely removes one or more packages along with their configuration files. This is more thorough than 'remove' and ensures all traces of the package are deleted from the system.

autoremove.name: Auto Remove
autoremove.description: Removes packages that were automatically installed to satisfy dependencies for other packages and are no longer needed. This helps clean up the system after packages are removed. It's good practice to run this periodically.

clean.name: Clean
clean.description: Clears the local repository of retrieved package files (the cache in /var/cache/apt/archives/). It removes all .deb files, freeing up disk space. Useful if you need to reclaim space, but running 'install' or 'upgrade' afterwards will re-download packages.

autoclean.name: Auto Clean
autoclean.description: Clears the local repository of retrieved package files, but only removes package files that can no longer be downloaded (they are obsolete and have been replaced by newer versions in the repository). It is a safer way to free up space than 'clean'.

check.name: Check
check.description: Updates the package cache and checks for broken dependencies. It's a diagnostic tool to verify the consistency of the package management system.

-y.name: Assume Yes
-y.description: Automatically answers 'yes' to all prompts, assuming 'yes' as the answer to all confirmation dialogs. This is useful for non-interactive scripts but should be used with caution.

--dry-run.name: Dry Run
--dry-run.description: Simulates the actions that would be performed (like install, upgrade, remove) without actually making any changes to the system. It shows what would be done, which is excellent for testing and verification.

-s.name: Simulate (Synonym for --dry-run)
-s.description: Same as --dry-run. Performs a simulation of events.

-q.name: Quiet
-q.description: Produces less output, running in a quieter mode. Useful for scripting.

--no-install-recommends.name: No Install Recommends
--no-install-recommends.description: Do not install recommended packages, only install dependencies. This can result in a more minimal installation.

--install-suggests.name: Install Suggests
--install-suggests.description: Consider suggested packages as dependencies to install. This installs more packages than the default.

-f.name: Fix Broken
-f.description: Attempts to correct a system with broken dependencies in place. This is often used after a failed package operation.

--reinstall.name: Reinstall
--reinstall.description: Reinstall the specified package(s). Useful if package files are corrupted but configuration should be preserved.

--download-only.name: Download Only
--download-only.description: Downloads the specified packages to the cache (/var/cache/apt/archives/) but does not unpack or install them. Installation can be performed later when offline.

no_flags.output: help information for the command

update.output: Standard repository index update output listing hits, gets, and ignores.

upgrade.output: Standard output listing packages to be upgraded, asking for confirmation, and showing installation progress.

dist-upgrade.output: Standard output showing packages to be upgraded, newly installed, or removed.

install.output: Standard output showing package retrieval, dependency resolution, and installation progress for 'vim'.

remove.output: Standard output showing package removal but retaining configuration files.

purge.output: Standard output showing complete removal of the 'vim' package and its configs.

autoremove.output: Standard output listing automatically installed, unused packages to be removed.

clean.output: No output on success; clears the package cache directory.

autoclean.output: Standard output listing obsolete .deb files being deleted.

-y.output: Standard installation output for 'curl' without asking for confirmation.

--dry-run.output: Simulated output showing what would happen if 'nano' were removed.

-s.output: Simulated output of an upgrade operation.

--no-install-recommends.output: Standard installation output for 'apache2' without its recommended packages.

--install-suggests.output: Standard installation output for 'wireshark' including suggested packages.

-f.output: Standard output attempting to fix broken dependencies.

--download-only.output: Standard output downloading the 'git' package to cache without installing it.

commands.name: apt-listchanges
commands.description: A tool for Debian and Ubuntu systems that displays changelogs and news between the currently installed version and a new version of a package when upgrading via APT. It can be integrated into APT's workflow (via apt.conf hooks) or run manually. It helps users understand what changes (bug fixes, new features, security patches) will be introduced by an update before it is applied.

--apt.name: APT Mode
--apt.description: Simulate APT behavior. Expects package files (.deb) or .changes files on stdin or as arguments, similar to how APT hooks invoke the tool. This is the default mode when invoked from APT hooks.

--config=FILE.name: Configuration File
--config=FILE.description: Use the specified configuration file instead of the default /etc/apt-listchanges.conf or user-specific configs.

--debug.name: Debug Mode
--debug.description: Enable verbose debugging output to stderr.

--email.name: Email Output
--email.description: Send the output via email instead of displaying it on the terminal. Requires mail transport agent (like sendmail) to be configured.

--email-address=ADDRESS.name: Email Address
--email-address=ADDRESS.description: Specify the recipient email address when using --email. Overrides the 'email_address' configuration option.

--from=ADDRESS.name: From Address
--from=ADDRESS.description: Specify the sender email address when using --email. Overrides the 'from' configuration option.

--frontend=TYPE.name: Frontend
--frontend=TYPE.description: Choose the user interface. Valid types are: 'pager' (uses $PAGER, default in terminals), 'browser' (uses text-based browser), 'xdg' (uses xdg-open), 'text' (plain text to stdout), 'mail' (for email), 'none' (no output, just exit code).

--headers.name: Include Headers
--headers.description: Include archive and package headers in the output. This is the default for non-APT mode.

--help.name: Help
--help.description: Display a brief help message and exit.

--history=FILE.name: History File
--history=FILE.description: Use a specific history file to track which changelog entries have already been seen.

--no-headers.name: Suppress Headers
--no-headers.description: Do not include archive and package headers in the output. This is the default for APT mode.

--profile=NAME.name: Configuration Profile
--profile=NAME.description: Use a specific profile defined in the configuration file. Profiles allow different settings (e.g., frontend, email) for different contexts.

--save-seen.name: Save Seen State
--save-seen.description: Update the history database to mark displayed items as 'seen', so they won't be shown again in future runs.

--smtp-host=HOST.name: SMTP Host
--smtp-host=HOST.description: Specify the SMTP server host for direct email sending (when not using sendmail).

--smtp-password=PASS.name: SMTP Password
--smtp-password=PASS.description: Specify the password for SMTP authentication.

--smtp-username=USER.name: SMTP Username
--smtp-username=USER.description: Specify the username for SMTP authentication.

--which=WHICH.name: Content Selection
--which=WHICH.description: Select which information to display: 'news' (only Debian NEWS), 'changelogs' (only changelogs), or 'both' (default).

no_flags.output: # Displays changelog and news entries for the given .deb file using default frontend (usually a pager).

--apt.output: # Processes the package file as if invoked by APT, typically suppressing headers.

--config=FILE.output: # Runs with a custom global configuration file.

--debug.output: # Shows debug information mixed with normal output on stderr.

--email.output: # Emails the changelog output to the specified address instead of displaying it.

--frontend=TYPE.output: # Prints the changelog as plain text directly to the terminal without a pager.

--headers / --no-headers.output: # Includes the 'Archive: ...' and 'Package: ...' headers in the output, which are sometimes omitted by default.

--help.output: # Displays the usage summary and available options.

--profile=NAME.output: # Uses settings from the 'urgent' profile defined in the configuration file.

--save-seen.output: # Marks the displayed changelog entries as 'seen' in the history database.

--which=WHICH.output: # Displays only Debian NEWS entries, not the detailed changelog.

-c FILE.output: # Same as --config using the short form.

-f TYPE.output: # Opens the output in a text-based web browser (like lynx or w3m).

-a.output: # Same as --apt using the short form.

commands.name: apt-sortpkgs
commands.description: A utility from the APT package management suite that sorts package index files (Packages, Sources, .diff/Index) in a uniform and reproducible way. It is primarily used internally by apt tools to ensure consistency and proper merging of package lists from different repositories. It reads from a source index file, sorts the entries, and writes to a destination file.

-c.name: config-file
-c.description: Specify a configuration file to use. APT will read this configuration file instead of the default ones.

-o.name: option
-o.description: Set a configuration option directly. This overrides configuration file settings. Syntax is -o APT::SortPackages::Source=1 or -o Dir::State::status=/var/lib/dpkg/status.

-s.name: source
-s.description: Sort a source index file (Sources), instead of a binary package index file (Packages). This is implied if the input filename contains 'Sources'.

-h.name: help
-h.description: Display a concise help message summarizing the command usage and options.

--version.name: version
--version.description: Display the version information of the apt-sortpkgs utility and exit.

no_flags.output: The sorted contents are written to standard output. To save to a file, redirect the output: apt-sortpkgs /tmp/unsorted_Packages > /tmp/sorted_Packages

-s.output: The source index file is sorted and the result is printed to standard output.

-c.output: Sorts the package file using the custom configuration specified in apt.conf.custom.

-o.output: Sorts the package file using a custom, non-default sorting option (example: random). The output is the sorted list.

-h.output: The standard help information for the command.

--version.output: The version information for the command.

commands.name: ar
commands.description: The 'ar' (archive) command is used to create, modify, and extract from static library archives (files with the .a extension). It bundles multiple object files (.o) into a single archive file, which is primarily used by the linker during program compilation. 'ar' can create new archives, insert, delete, extract, or list members (object files) within an archive. It is a fundamental tool for managing static libraries in Unix-like systems.

r.name: Replace/Insert
r.description: Replace existing members or insert new members into the archive. If the member does not exist, it is appended. If used with 'u', only replaces members that are newer than the archive copy.

c.name: Create
c.description: Create the archive silently. Suppresses the warning message that is normally issued when 'ar' creates a new archive file.

s.name: Write Index
s.description: Create or update an index of the archive's contents. This index is used by the linker to speed up symbol lookup. Equivalent to running 'ranlib' on the archive.

d.name: Delete
d.description: Delete the specified member(s) from the archive. The archive is modified directly.

q.name: Quick Append
q.description: Quickly append files to the end of the archive without checking for duplicates or replacing existing members. This is faster but can create duplicate object files.

t.name: Table of Contents
t.description: Display a list (table) of the members (object files) contained in the archive. If members are specified, only list those.

x.name: Extract
x.description: Extract the specified member(s) from the archive into the current directory. If no members are given, all members are extracted.

u.name: Update
u.description: Update the archive. Only replace members that are newer than the archive copy. Must be used in conjunction with 'r'.

v.name: Verbose
v.description: Operate in verbose mode. Shows detailed information about the actions being performed (e.g., which files are being added, deleted, or extracted).

m.name: Move/Reorder
m.description: Move members within the archive. This allows reordering of existing members. Requires additional positioning arguments ('a', 'b', or 'i').

p.name: Print
p.description: Print the contents of the specified archive member(s) to standard output. If no members are given, prints all members.

o.name: Preserve Original Dates
o.description: Preserve the original modification timestamps of members when extracting them ('x' mode).

i.name: Insert Before
i.description: When inserting with 'r' or moving with 'm', place the new file before the specified member (requires a positional member name). Synonymous with 'b'.

b.name: Insert Before
b.description: Same as '-i'. Place the new file before the specified member when inserting or moving.

a.name: Insert After
a.description: When inserting with 'r' or moving with 'm', place the new file after the specified member (requires a positional member name).

l.name: Placeholder
l.description: Accepted for compatibility but has no effect in modern 'ar' implementations.

N.name: Use Count
N.description: Use the count parameter. When there are multiple members with the same name in the archive, select the nth instance (used with 'd', 'x', 't', etc.).

S.name: Do Not Build Symbol Table
S.description: Do not build an archive symbol table. This can speed up operations but makes the archive unusable by the linker without later 'ranlib'.

T.name: Thin Archive
T.description: Create or operate on a 'thin' archive. A thin archive contains only symbolic links to the original object files, not the actual file data, saving space. Requires 'r' or 'q' to create.

h.name: Help
h.description: Display a help message summarizing the command-line options and syntax.

V.name: Version
V.description: Display version information for the 'ar' program.

no_flags.output:
add.o
subtract.o
multiply.o
divide.o

r.output: (No output if successful, creates/updates libutils.a with index)

c.output: (No warning, creates libnew.a if it doesn't exist)

q.output: (No output, appends newfile.o even if a duplicate exists)

x.output: (No output, extracts specific.o to current directory)

u.output: (No output, replaces newer.o only if the file newer.o is newer than the copy in the archive)

m.output: (No output, repositions moved.o after existing.o in the archive)

p.output: (First 5 lines of the binary/object file content)

o.output: (Extracts all members, keeping their original timestamps)

N.output: (No output, extracts the second member named common.o)

S.output: (No output, adds file.o without updating symbol table)

T.output: (No output, creates a thin archive with relative links)

h.output: Standard help information for the command.

V.output: Standard version information for the command.

commands.name: arborist
commands.description: The `arborist` command is part of the Node Package Manager (npm) ecosystem, specifically used for managing the node_modules directory tree and package installations. It is a low-level library/tool that npm uses internally for deterministic, reproducible, and efficient management of the dependency tree. It handles operations like reading package.json files, building dependency trees, calculating ideal tree layouts, and performing physical actions on the node_modules folder (extracting, moving, linking packages). It is designed to be more reliable and performant than the legacy npm installer, using a more sophisticated algorithm to resolve package placement conflicts and optimize the file system structure. It powers the `npm install` command in npm v7 and above.

audit.name: Audit
audit.description: Perform a security audit on the project dependencies. This checks the installed packages against known vulnerabilities in the npm audit database and can produce a report or fix issues.

audit-level.name: Audit Level
audit-level.description: Specify the minimum vulnerability level to cause the audit command to fail. Must be used with --audit.

audit-fix.name: Audit Fix
audit-fix.description: Attempt to automatically install compatible updates to vulnerable dependencies. Must be used with --audit.

dry-run.name: Dry Run
dry-run.description: Perform a simulation of the command without making any actual changes to the file system. It reports what would be done.

force.name: Force
force.description: Force Arborist to proceed with operations it might otherwise skip or consider unsafe, such as removing potentially required packages or overwriting files.

global.name: Global
global.description: Operate in global mode. The package will be installed into the global node_modules folder instead of the local project's node_modules.

ignore-scripts.name: Ignore Scripts
ignore-scripts.description: Do not execute package lifecycle scripts (e.g., preinstall, install, postinstall) during the installation process.

legacy-peer-deps.name: Legacy Peer Dependencies
legacy-peer-deps.description: Ignore peerDependencies when installing, using the legacy npm v6-style behavior instead of the strict peer dependency resolution introduced in npm v7.

omit.name: Omit Dependency Types
omit.description: Exclude certain types of dependencies from installation. Can be 'dev', 'optional', or 'peer'. Can be specified multiple times.

package-lock-only.name: Package Lock Only
package-lock-only.description: Update only the package-lock.json file without touching the node_modules directory.

prefer-dedupe.name: Prefer Dedupe
prefer-dedupe.description: Prefer to deduplicate packages if possible, reducing duplication in the node_modules tree.

progress.name: Progress
progress.description: Show a progress bar during installation (when set to true). Disable with 'false'.

save.name: Save
save.description: Update the project's package.json file to include the installed package as a dependency. This is the default behavior for `npm install <pkg>`.

save-dev.name: Save Dev
save-dev.description: Update the project's package.json file to include the installed package as a development dependency (devDependencies).

save-optional.name: Save Optional
save-optional.description: Update the project's package.json file to include the installed package as an optional dependency (optionalDependencies).

save-peer.name: Save Peer
save-peer.description: Update the project's package.json file to include the installed package as a peer dependency (peerDependencies). Usually used with --save-dev.

strict-peer-deps.name: Strict Peer Dependencies
strict-peer-deps.description: Fail the installation if any unresolved peer dependencies are encountered, enforcing strict correctness.

workspace.name: Workspace
workspace.description: Enable workspaces and operate on a specific workspace (or all workspaces if no argument is given). Used in monorepo setups.

workspaces.name: Workspaces
workspaces.description: Enable workspaces and operate on all of them. Equivalent to `--workspace` with no arguments.

no_flags.output: The arborist command is typically not invoked directly by end users. It is a library used programmatically by npm. Running it standalone with no arguments may result in an error or show internal usage information.

audit.output: Security audit report showing vulnerabilities in the current project's dependencies.

audit-level.output: Security audit that will exit with a failure code only if vulnerabilities of level 'high' or 'critical' are found.

audit-fix.output: Security audit that will automatically install semver-compatible updates to packages with vulnerabilities where possible.

dry-run.output: A detailed simulation report of what packages would be installed, updated, or removed, without making changes.

force.output: Forces a complete reification (rebuild) of the node_modules tree, ignoring some safety checks.

global.output: Output is the standard installation process log for a global package.

ignore-scripts.output: Output is the standard installation process log, but no lifecycle scripts (like 'postinstall') are executed.

legacy-peer-deps.output: Output is the standard installation process log, using npm v6's more permissive peer dependency resolution.

omit.output: Output is the standard installation process log, but development dependencies (devDependencies) are not installed.

package-lock-only.output: Only the package-lock.json file is updated. No node_modules changes occur.

prefer-dedupe.output: Output is the standard installation process log, with the tree optimized to deduplicate packages more aggressively.

progress.output: Output is the standard installation process log, but without the visual progress bar.

save-dev.output: Output is the standard installation process log for the 'lodash' package, which is added to devDependencies in package.json.

save-optional.output: Output is the standard installation process log for the 'eslint' package, which is added to optionalDependencies in package.json.

strict-peer-deps.output: Installation will fail if there are any unmet or incorrectly versioned peer dependencies.

workspaces.output: Output is the standard installation process log, but the operation is performed across all workspaces defined in the root package.json.

name: arch
description: The arch command prints the machine's architecture type. It is equivalent to running 'uname -m'. This command is useful for determining whether the system is running on 32-bit or 64-bit hardware, or identifying specific processor architectures like ARM or x86. It is commonly used in scripts to conditionally execute architecture-specific operations or install correct binary packages.

--help.name: Help
--help.description: Display a help message explaining the command's usage and available options, then exit.

--version.name: Version
--version.description: Output version information about the arch command and then exit.

--help.output: Standard help information for the command.

--version.output: Standard version information for the command.

name: bash
description: The Bourne Again SHell (bash) is a command processor that runs in a text window and allows users to interact with the operating system by typing commands. It's a sh-compatible shell that incorporates useful features from the Korn shell (ksh) and C shell (csh). Bash is the default shell on most Linux distributions and macOS.

c.name: Read commands from string
c.description: Reads and executes commands from the first non-option argument, then exits. Any remaining arguments are assigned to the positional parameters, starting with $0.

i.name: Interactive shell
i.description: Forces the shell to run interactively, even if input and output do not appear to be a terminal. Interactive shells read commands from standard input and enable job control by default.

l.name: Login shell
l.description: Makes bash act as if it were invoked as a login shell. This means it will read and execute commands from system-wide and user-specific login shell startup files like /etc/profile and ~/.bash_profile.

r.name: Restricted shell
r.description: Starts a restricted shell session, which restricts certain operations like changing directories, setting the PATH, or using commands containing slashes. This provides a more controlled environment.

s.name: Read commands from standard input
s.description: Reads commands from standard input. If this option is used, any remaining arguments become positional parameters (starting with $0). This is the default behavior when no file arguments are provided and no -c option is given.

D.name: Print list of double-quoted strings
D.description: ' style strings in the program that are subject to language translation (for internationalization). These are strings marked for translation.

O.name: Set shell option
O.description: Enables the specified shell option (shopt option). The option name should be provided as an argument. Use '+O' to disable the option.

O-.name: Disable shell option
O-.description: Disables the specified shell option (shopt option). The option name should be provided as an argument.

version.name: Display version information
version.description: Shows version information for this instance of bash and then exits.

debugger.name: Enable debugger
debugger.description: Arranges for the debugger profile to be executed before the shell starts. Turns on extended debugging mode and shell function tracing.

dump-po-strings.name: Dump portable object strings
dump-po-strings.description: Equivalent to -D, but outputs in GNU gettext portable object file format.

help.name: Display help
help.description: Shows a usage message summarizing command line options and then exits.

init-file.name: Specify initialization file
init-file.description: Uses the specified file instead of the standard initialization files (~/.bashrc, etc.) as the shell startup file. Can be abbreviated as --rcfile.

login.name: Login shell
login.description: Equivalent to -l, makes bash a login shell.

noediting.name: Disable command line editing
noediting.description: Disables the use of the GNU Readline library for command line editing. Useful in scripts or when Readline causes issues.

noprofile.name: Skip profile files
noprofile.description: Prevents bash from reading the system-wide startup file (/etc/profile) and any personal initialization file (~/.bash_profile, ~/.bash_login, or ~/.profile).

norc.name: Skip rc files
norc.description: Prevents bash from reading and executing the personal initialization file ~/.bashrc. This option is on by default if the shell is invoked as sh.

posix.name: POSIX mode
posix.description: Changes bash behavior to follow the POSIX standard more closely, disabling bash-specific extensions.

restricted.name: Restricted shell
restricted.description: Equivalent to -r, starts a restricted shell.

verbose.name: Verbose mode
verbose.description: Equivalent to setting the -v option, causes shell to print shell input lines as they are read. Useful for debugging.

wordexp.name: Test word expansion
wordexp.description: Disables command execution and instead performs word expansion only. Used for testing and debugging shell scripts.

no_flags.output: Starts a new interactive bash shell session.

i.output: Runs script.sh in an interactive shell context.

l.output: Starts bash as a login shell, reading login-specific initialization files.

r.output: Starts a restricted bash shell with limited capabilities.

D.output: List of internationalized strings in the script.

O.output: Starts bash with extended pattern matching (extglob) enabled.

O-.output: Starts bash with history expansion disabled.

debugger.output: Starts bash with debugger profiling enabled.

dump-po-strings.output: Portable object strings in GNU gettext format.

dump-strings.output: List of internationalized strings in the script.

init-file.output: Starts bash using ~/custom_bashrc as the startup file instead of ~/.bashrc.

login.output: Equivalent to bash -l, starts a login shell.

noediting.output: Starts bash without Readline command line editing.

noprofile.output: Starts bash without reading system or user profile files.

restricted.output: Equivalent to bash -r, starts a restricted shell.

wordexp.output: Performs word expansion on 'echo *' without executing the command.

name: basename
description: The basename command strips directory and suffix from filenames. It removes any leading directory components from the given pathname and optionally removes a trailing suffix if specified. This is particularly useful in shell scripting to extract just the filename from a full path or to manipulate filenames programmatically.

-a, --multiple.name: Multiple
-a, --multiple.description: Support multiple arguments and treat each as a NAME. The command will process all provided arguments, outputting each result on a separate line.

-s, --suffix.name: Suffix
-s, --suffix.description: Remove a trailing SUFFIX from the NAME. This is the older, single-argument form of suffix removal. It removes the specified suffix string if it matches the end of the basename.
-s, --suffix.syntax: basename -s SUFFIX NAME [NAME ...] OR basename --suffix=SUFFIX NAME [NAME ...]

-z, --zero.name: Zero
-z, --zero.description: Separate output with NUL characters instead of newlines. This is useful when processing filenames that may contain newlines or other whitespace, ensuring safe parsing.

--help.name: Help
--help.description: Display a help message with usage information and a summary of available options, then exit successfully.

--version.name: Version
--version.description: Output version information about the command, then exit successfully.

no_flags.output: report.txt

--help.output: Standard help information for the command.

--version.output: Standard version information for the command.

name: batcat
description: A cat(1) clone with syntax highlighting and Git integration. It provides syntax highlighting for a large number of programming and markup languages, integrates with Git to show modifications, supports automatic paging, displays non-printable characters, and can concatenate multiple files. It is designed to be a drop-in replacement for cat but with greatly enhanced features for interactive use.

--language.name: Explicit Language
--language.description: Explicitly set the language for syntax highlighting. Overrides automatic detection.

--style.name: Output Style
--style.description: Configure the elements included in the output (e.g., line numbers, header, grid). Comma-separated list of 'auto', 'full', 'plain', 'changes', 'header', 'grid', 'numbers', 'rule', 'snip'.

--theme.name: Color Theme
--theme.description: Set the color theme for syntax highlighting. Use '--list-themes' to see available options.

--list-themes.name: List Themes
--list-themes.description: Display a list of all available syntax highlighting themes.

--list-languages.name: List Languages
--list-languages.description: Display a list of all supported languages for syntax highlighting.

--show-all.name: Show Non-Printable
--show-all.description: Show non-printable characters (space, tab, newline, etc.) using special symbols.

--number.name: Line Numbers
--number.description: Only show line numbers, no other margin elements.

--color.name: When to Color
--color.description: Specify when to use colored output: 'auto', 'never', 'always'.

--paging.name: Paging Mode
--paging.description: Specify when to use the pager: 'auto', 'never', 'always'.

--terminal-width.name: Terminal Width
--terminal-width.description: Explicitly set the terminal width. Prefix with '+' or '-' to offset from the actual width.

--tabs.name: Tab Width
--tabs.description: Set the number of spaces to display for a tab character.

--decorations.name: When to Decorate
--decorations.description: Specify when to show decorations (header, grid, line numbers): 'auto', 'never', 'always'.

--file-name.name: File Name
--file-name.description: Display the file name as a header, even for a single file.

--diff.name: Diff Mode
--diff.description: Show line-level Git modifications by comparing against the index (green for added, red for removed).

--diff-context.name: Diff Context Lines
--diff-context.description: Show N lines of context around changes in --diff mode.

no_flags.output: Output is the syntax-highlighted contents of file.txt with a header, line numbers, and Git changes if applicable, paged through a pager (like less).

--language.output: Output is script.py highlighted as Python code, even if the file extension is not .py or detection fails.

--plain.output: Output is the plain, un-highlighted contents of file.json (identical to standard cat).

--style.output: Output shows only line numbers and a file header, with no grid lines or rule.

--theme.output: Output is file.py highlighted using the 'TwoDark' color theme.

--list-themes.output: Output is a list of all available syntax highlighting themes.

--list-languages.output: Output is a list of all supported programming/markup languages.

--show-all.output: Output shows config.yaml with spaces, tabs, and line endings visualized as symbols (, , ).

--number.output: Output shows notes.md with line numbers but no header, grid, or Git integration.

--color.output: Output forces colorized output of log.txt even when piping to another command.

--paging.output: Output prints the entire README file to the terminal at once, without using a pager.

--pager.output: Output pages large_file.log using the command 'less -F'.

--wrap.output: Output displays wide_data.csv without line wrapping, allowing horizontal scrolling.

--terminal-width.output: Output formats report.md as if the terminal is 80 columns wide.

--tabs.output: Output displays tab characters in source.go as 2 spaces wide.

--decorations.output: Output sends plain, non-decorated JSON to jq for processing.

--file-name.output: Output shows 'intro.txt' as a header, even though only one file is displayed.

--diff.output: Output highlights lines added (green) or removed (red) relative to the Git index.

--diff-context.output: Output shows Git changes in file.py with 3 lines of context around each change.

--force-colorization.output: Output forces color codes in the first 20 lines of file.rb when piped to head.

--help.output: Output is the help information for the batcat command.

--version.output: Output is the version information for batcat.

name: bc
description: bc (basic calculator) is an arbitrary-precision numeric processing language and calculator that supports interactive execution of statements. It resembles the C programming language in syntax but provides unlimited precision arithmetic with as many digits as needed. bc can perform mathematical operations (+, -, *, /, %, ^), has built-in functions, supports conditional statements, loops, and user-defined functions. It's commonly used for precision calculations, financial computations, and complex mathematical scripting.

-h.name: Help
-h.description: Print a help message with usage information and exit.

-i.name: Interactive
-i.description: Force interactive mode. Normally bc runs interactively if standard input is from a terminal.

-l.name: Math Library
-l.description: Define the standard math library. This loads pre-defined mathematical functions (s, c, a for sin, cos, arctan; l for natural log; e for exponential; j for Bessel function). Also sets scale (decimal places) to 20.

-w.name: Warn
-w.description: Give warnings for extensions to POSIX bc. POSIX bc does not support certain features like the 'print' statement or 'if', 'for', 'while' constructs. This flag warns when these are used.

-s.name: Standard
-s.description: Process exactly the POSIX bc language. This disables extensions (like the 'print' statement) and forces strict POSIX compliance.

-q.name: Quiet
-q.description: Do not print the normal GNU bc welcome banner on startup.

-v.name: Version
-v.description: Print the version number and copyright information, then exit.

-e.name: Expression
-e.description: Evaluate the provided expression. Multiple -e options can be given; they are processed in order. If also using -f or a file argument, expressions from -e are processed first.

-f.name: File
-f.description: Read and process code from the specified file. Multiple -f options can be given; they are processed in order. If a file argument is also provided on the command line (without -f), it is processed after -f files.

-i.output: Starts an interactive bc session. User can then input expressions like '5 * 20' and get output '100'.

-w.output: Runtime warning (func=main, adr=3): POSIX does not allow `print' statement (will output 'hello' then the warning message)

-s.output: parse error (POSIX bc does not support 'if' statement)
